awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Enabling a strong DKIST start - The Magnetic Structure of Solar Filaments
awd_abstract_narration:
On the Sun, magnetic fields are found in both active and quiet large structures forming and erupting from the Sun's surface called solar filaments. The investigators propose to make and study a large data set that measures the magnetic field inside these filaments, including both erupting and non-erupting configurations, of both active and quiet solar filaments. These studies will cover all steps in a solar filament's lifetime, from formation to stability to eruption. Obtaining the complete magnetic field data set required to study solar filaments is only now possible using a medium-sized telescope equipped with special instrumentation, now available to the investigators.  The investigators will be ready to study observations of the solar filaments made at greater resolutions by the new Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope when it begins operation.  This project supports the mission of the NSF by promoting our understanding of magnetic field structure and activity at the Sun. The investigators will include a graduate student and a post-doctoral associate to support the research and learn data analysis techniques.

Magnetism exists as linear, sheared structures that allows for filament formation; the lack of cross-field drift in the structure stabilizes the filament plasma from thermalization and collapse; and only magnetism can rapidly rearrange structure and result in eruption. Three specific science questions will be addressed: What is the magnetic field configuration of forming solar filaments?  What is the magnetic field configuration of stable solar filaments?  What is the magnetic field configuration of a filament prior to eruption?  To address these, the investigators set three specific objectives: Define and obtain ten spectropolarimetric sequences in the He I absorption line at 10830A, in order to study filament formation. Classify solar filament structure by producing a pipeline to reduce, analyze, and interpret these spectropolarimetric data. Identify those magnetic configurations prior to a loss of filament stability. Data analysis requires the training of personnel in running and expanding the HAZEL inversion code into pipeline in order to study the magnetic structure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project is part of a collaborative research project aiming to help ensure a strong start of the new NSF flagship solar telescope - the Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope (DKIST, commissioned in December 2021). This project aims to gather new information on the magnetic and dynamic properties of solar filaments before, during, and after their eruptions, which should lead to better understanding of the triggers and eruption mechanism of solar filaments. The project team consists of scientists from the New Mexico State University (NMSU, Lead Science Team), National Solar Observatory (NSO), and University of Hawaii (Instrumentation Support). This research was carried out at the Dunn Solar Telescope (DST) of the National Solar Observatory in Sunspot, New Mexico, using the Facility IR Specropolarimeter (FIRS, constrcuted for DST by the UH PI), which conducted the pioneering filament magnetic field measurments. FIRS is a predecessor of the powerful new instruments (the Diffraction-Limited Near-IR Spectropolarimeter - DL-NIRSP, and the Cryogenic Near-IR Spectropolarimeter - Cryo-NIRSP) that are part of the suit of first-generation facility instruments of the DKIST. The insight gained from this research helps prepare the researchers prepare for the continued study of filament magnetic fields and eruptions using the new instruments on DKIST. 

This project successfully obtained 167 observations of filaments, and developed the data reduction pipeline to derive the magnetic fields and Doppler velocity maps of the filaments. The fully processed science data are now available to the solar physics community at NMSU website (http://ssoc.nmsu.edu/filaments2.php). 

Study of data obtained during the project period showed that erupting filaments didn't launch into space from a complete standstill, but rather had a low upward velocity of approximately 6 km/s before the eruptions. Also, rather than erupting as a coherent structure, the erupting filaments contained multiple threads of plasma, each with their own velocity evolution. These new, and detailed information will enable us to design new observations on DKIST to further advance our knowledge of the filament processes. 

This project has trained a junior researcher (Dr. Shuo Wang) in the field of solar spectropolarimetry, in particular, in the technique of Hanle effect magnetic field measurements to derive the filament magnetic fields, and prepared Dr. Wang for a career in the bew era of DKIST. This project therefore also contributes to the training of a new generation users of DKIST. The data reduction pipeline will accelerate the establishment of the data reduction pipeline at DKIST data center.
